awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Cognitive Communications Payload Module for CubeSat Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to advance communications and on-board processing capabilities for small satellites or CubeSats, which is important with growing civil and commercial demand for satellite communications services.  The proposed payload module provides a number of cognitive communications functions focused on intelligent networking capabilities for CubeSat platforms and swarms. These functions enable robust, reliable global connectivity by allowing for customer CubeSats to efficiently and autonomously communicate within swarms and with other networks for applications including Earth observation, sensing, situational awareness, new space, and communications. 

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will develop and demonstrate a flexible, comprehensive cognitive communications payload module to enhance communications functions in networking for CubeSat platforms and swarms. This project will demonstrate the technical feasibility of the proposed innovation, apply advanced and emerging on-board processing and communications technologies, and develop and integrate hardware and software to develop a prototype payload module for CubeSat applications. The prototype will perform several cognitive functions allowing for intelligent networking for CubeSat platforms and swarms: intelligent routing, network self-healing, ad-hoc networking with other available networks, and data store and forward capabilities for sparse networks and network build-up phase. Autonomous operation will improve data transmission, data packaging and routing, latency mitigation, and user-initiated services for commercial, government, and academic CubeSat operators.  This effort will focus on three key areas: 1) developing the cognitive engine architecture and software, 2) acquiring and integrating a software-defined radio and single-board computer, and 3) developing an appropriate API. The objective of this project is to prototype the cognitive communications payload module in preparation for testing, demonstration, flight qualification, and commercialization.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
During Phase I, Comsat Architects demonstrated the feasibility of advanced link optimization and intelligent routing capabilities for our Comprehensive Cognitive Communications Payload Module (C3PM), an innovative module that enables autonomous communications functionality for CubeSats and constellations. To do this, we developed and implemented the foundational hardware (HW) and software (SW) assemblies for the C3PM, including algorithms that could autonomously optimize communication links and route data through a constellation. The C3PM is an advanced communication and computing system for CubeSat platforms that utilizes cognitive technologies, machine learning (ML) algorithms, and advanced, miniaturized computing and communications HW to achieve autonomous functionality and inter-satellite cooperation for CubeSats in a constellation. The initial functions the C3PM will perform are as follows: (1) intelligent routing, (2) data store and forwarding for sparse networks of constellation build-up phase, and (3) link performance optimization. Using standard HW and SW interfaces, the C3PM can integrate with a variety of SDRs and standard CubeSat buses. 

The C3PM greatly advances the CubeSat state of the art by providing commercial and government CubeSat operators with a unique, novel payload module designed to enable cognitive communications and on-board processing functions. Comsat Architects’ research indicates that though cognitive technologies are of great interest to researchers and the CubeSat industry, our product will be the first commercially available to provide comprehensive cognitive communications functions for CubeSat applications. CubeSat operators have indicated they are interested in solutions alleviating CubeSat swarms’ expensive burden on ground stations and high data latency. The C3PM’s on-board processing, intelligent routing, and link optimization functions allow data to be processed on the spacecraft itself instead of a ground station, and for that data to reach Earth through the fastest, most efficient path.

At the end of Phase I, we successfully developed the Cognitive Engine SW and acquired initial HW to establish the feasibility of the operations and key functions of the C3PM. We successfully integrated the development SBC, including a high-performance system on a chip (SOC), and SDR and installed our CE and API SW to build an engineering assembly as our initial prototype unit. After testing this assembly on the Communication Testbed, we verified that the C3PM HW and SW had successfully integrated and that the CE effectively allowed our system to operate and learn. We have established our module’s feasibility through verifying functionality of the link optimization and the routing pipeline, selection and acquisition of high-performance HW, successful development of CE SW, the development of a Radio API, and integration testing of the HW and SW in an engineering assembly.

The C3PM pushes forward the CubeSat state of the art significantly, providing much higher communications and on-board processing capabilities than are currently available for small satellites. The C3PM’s innovative Cognitive Engine enables advanced link optimization and intelligent routing for efficient node-to-node data transfer within a network with reduced latency. Comsat Architects has identified several application areas the C3PM can benefit including Earth observation, sensing, situational awareness, space Internet, and communications. Outside of commercial applications, the C3PM’s intelligent routing capabilities can benefit US national security and defense, science, and space exploration initiatives by allowing important information to reach decision makers more quickly. 

These accomplishments demonstrate that the C3PM, once developed, can perform cognitive functions which can now be developed to incorporate more advanced features. Going forward, we will build upon these accomplishments by developing other components of the CE, addressing remaining compatibility issues, and optimizing Phase I SW. Our Phase I successes have given us a framework to expand vital CE SW in Phase II. After working with our current development SBCs, we have a thorough understanding of all the interfaces and processing power necessary to develop and test a C3PM engineering prototype.

The accomplishments of our Phase I R&D effort have provided Comsat Architects with a strong framework for developing a prototype C3PM in Phase II and ultimately a product ready for market. The HW and SW acquired and built has highlighted that our module can perform the high-level link optimization and intelligent routing laid out in our R&D objectives. We will build upon this foundation in Phase II to develop a fully functioning prototype C3PM for demonstration in a relevant environment, bringing the C3PM a critical step closer toward utilizing its advanced cognitive communications capabilities on a CubeSat in orbit.
